markhoebeke wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> I'm quite new to Junit ant want to use Eclipse to carry out unit
> testing of modules using AspectJ.
> 
> However, as far as I understand, when the unit tests created in the
> Eclipse IDE are run, they are first compiled in the projects bin
> directory. A have found no way to customize the way they are compiled
> to use the AspectJ specific compilers. Hence, I cannot benefit of AOP
> when unit testing.
> 
> Is this just a technical matter, or is it politically
> (philosophically, theologically) wrong to try to perform unit testing
> on AOP components ?

Short answer: it's a technical matter.

Longer answer:
I have no direct experience with AOP "the AspectJ way", involving an 
intermediate compilation step, so this is an essay, rather than an 
experience report.

There is no philosophical reason not to test-drive AOP-related 
components. Especially when using class library implementations of AOP 
(example: Spring AOP), test-driving makes perfect sense, although 
remember Don't Test the Platform. Test your advice, and not how the tool 
applies your advice. If you're unsure how to specify cutpoints, 
joinpoints and the like, write some Learning Tests for doing so with 
simple bits of advice that are easy to verify. There's no need to test 
both at the same time.

I hope this helps.
